column4: Does that necessarily mean that initrd.gz for the gutsy live CD contains the module?
I would assume so, as well
but I'm getting strange errors
I'm netbooting the live CD
I mean, I'm serving the live CD via NFS
and I put the kernel in /var/lib/tftpboot
The computers that I'm trying to boot do not have disk drives
Right, that means adding the correct kernel module in the initrd.gz..
I built it from parts
However I imagine I also have to add the name of the module to a list in order for it to be loaded
not really due to the magic of udev
Does that mean I only need to put the module in the correct directory?
One more problem - if I compile the kernel module, I'll be compiling with a newer kernel, I think
you need to do more
because you just mentioned the live CD uses an older kernel
What do I need to do? Or is there a webpage that shows me how?
wow, these ops come from nowhere :)
hahah, and they don't even kick
they make people part
There's a command called mkinitrd, but I don't think I can use it to generate a live CD initrd
because I think the live CD initrd contains scripts that are specific to the live CD .. am I correct?
I guess nobody here really knows how to add a network driver to the initrd.gz on the live CD
what if I bluffed and said I was going to use Windows instead? =D
you compile a custom kernel
